Input.threadtitle: Understanding the concept of set.seed
Input.posts:
During the Lectures for Week 4 it talked about set.seed(), that it is used to make generating random numbers reproducible, but I am not quite grasping what that truly means. Can someone break it down for me so I understand that a bit better? Thanks
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
The argument passed to the set.seed() function should be thought of as the key to generating a specific sequence of pseudo-random values retuned by the function. Since computers like all digital devices are deterministic and randomness must be simulated via a random number generator (RNG) you never get a truly random number returned. For example, if you pass the number 1234 to set.seed() a specific range of possible values can be returned by the RNG. If you changed the value to pi a different range of possible values will be returned. Finally, if you again used the value 1234, then the same sequence of 'random' numbers would be returned in the same order. This behaviour is critical to reproducibility when verifying someone's analysis. Put another way, pretend you can pass a family name to set.seed(). Let's say you initially pass set.seed() the name of your family and each time a random sample is taken you get a subset of your entire family tree. Next you pass the name of your best friend's family to set.seed() and it returns a subset of his or her family tree. Then your best friend decides to run your code and passes his or her family name to set.seed() before fetching a random sample. The sample you and your best friend received when 'seeding' the random family member generator is precisely the same in terms of the persons' names and the order of appearance. Does this help you understand the functionality and purpose of set.seed()?
